explanation: Agent A is correct. The statement “(void) 0;” is an executed no-op: it has no side‑effects and removing it would not change program behaviour (other than trivial timing/optimization differences). Under the plain wording of MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 (“Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code”), such a no‑op is dead code. Note that authors often insert a (void)0; intentionally (for symmetry, to avoid “empty‑body” warnings or to make macro expansions syntactically valid); however that intent does not remove the fact that it meets the definition of dead code and so would need a documented justification or a deviation to be compliant with Rule 2.2.
